forecast.no_outcome_scenario: The Tax Reforms Bill remains in committee or only passes one chamber before the Sallah/June recess; harmonization or presidential assent slips into July or later. Alternatively, the measure is folded into a broader year-end Finance Act rather than advanced immediately.
forecast.yes_outcome_scenario: Leadership of the National Assembly prioritizes the Tax Reforms Bill, fast-tracks committee work and floor votes in both chambers by early-to-mid June, and President Tinubu quickly assents so the law is enacted before July 1.
forecast.rationale:
- Where things stand: As of April 25, 2025, reporting indicates a Tax Reforms Bill under consideration that would exempt real estate transactions from VAT. There is no evidence yet of passage by either chamber or presidential assent. My research assistant had no additional updates, suggesting we are still in the proposal/consideration phase.
- Time pressure: There are roughly 8 weeks left. Nigeria’s legislative process requires passage by both chambers, harmonization (if needed), and presidential assent. The National Assembly often takes a Sallah recess in June, compressing the calendar further.
- Status quo weighting: If nothing changes, the default is No—most bills do not move from introduction to full enactment in under two months, especially if bundled into a broader tax package that may invite stakeholder input and negotiation.
- Reasons it could still happen (why not lower): The administration has been active on fiscal reforms, and the measure is politically attractive as a pro-housing affordability step with potentially limited near-term revenue impact. Executive-priority bills can be fast-tracked, and the Assembly has precedent for moving such items quickly.
- Reasons it might slip (why not higher): The bill may contain broader or sensitive provisions that slow the package; committee review and harmonization take time; any pushback from revenue stakeholders (FIRS, states concerned about FAAC allocations) could delay; and the Assembly’s June schedule may be uneven due to holidays/recess. Even late-June passage could miss the deadline if assent/gazettal comes after July 1.
- What would move me up: Clear signs of acceleration—committee reports scheduled imminently, leadership signaling fast-track treatment, one chamber passing the bill in May, concurrent consideration in the other chamber, or credible reports that presidential assent will follow immediately upon passage.
- What would move me down: Reports of deferral to a year-end Finance Act, extended stakeholder consultations, opposition from key fiscal actors, or announcements of recess without the bill clearing second readings/committee in both chambers.
